text: Alone in a vast, serrated mountain range a hundred miles north of Los Angeles, it looks from the outside like a ru sprawl. The day is a gold sliver in a navy sky.

Writer DALTON TRUMBO, 41, debonair, heartfelt and combati is naked in a tub, his copyholder on a wood plank as the steam rises. INT. LAZY-T RANCH - TRUMBO’S STUDY - DAWN Like the whole home, beautifully appointed. Trumbo, kindl cigarette in its holder, attacks the keys of a typewriter his desk, the fastest two-fingered typist ever as we --

Taking in: - The American Booksellers National Book Award for his no Johnny Got His Gun. - The poster for his movie, Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo. - His Oscar nomination for the screenplay of Kitty Foyle. TIGHT ON TRUMBO’S TYPEWRITER As the inky letters CHOP movie dialogue across the white paper, Trumbo writing like a boxer working a speed bag -- MANNY: What do you want? (CONTINUED)

Thick with framed photos of: - Trumbo with KATHARINE HEPBURN at a United Refugee Commi dinner. - Trumbo as a World War II correspondent in his dress uniform, boarding a plane. - Trumbo in muddy fatigues, among battered SOLDIERS on a battle-scarred beach in the South Pacific. BACK TO A TIGHT CLOSE-UP OF TRUMBO’S WRITING Words racing across the page: What we all want.

In them, WE SEE both Trumbo’s furious pecking reflected o glass, animatedly overlaying stills under glass of: - Trumbo’s wife Cleo in a stunning portrait. - Trumbo and Cleo with their three children, blowing out Niki’s eighth birthday cake.

head_text.subj: BACK TO TRUMBO AT THE TYPEWRITER

text: Lemony morning light now paints the windows. Trumbo write To not die young, poor... And now we HEAR --
What do you want? What we all want. To not die young, poor... -- as the final words of Trumbo’s speech strike paper -- -..or alone. -- Trumbo SLAPS the return and in a WHITE BLUR we’re now
+..or alone. (CONTINUED)

EDWARD G. ROBINSON -- a charismatic, stocky man of 53, bo assertive and refined -- plays “MANNY,” stepping from a sedan, moving toward a SUPPORTING PLAYER as “ROCCO,” on h knees, bloody lip, torn jacket. “ROCCO” Manny, these guys... I don’t give ‘em what they’re after, they'll kill me. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/“MANNY” Hold it, Rocco. “Manny” takes out his revolver -- and aims it at “Rocco,” freezes as he stands. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (CONT’D) If we don’t fight these guys, sure, maybe you -- As “Manny” gestures with the gun, its cylinder dislodges the barrel -- and several bullets FLY out and comically CLATTER to the stage floor at Robinson’s feet. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/“MANNY” (CONT’D) Shit. The director is out of his chair and on his feet -- SAM W early 60s, sharp, authoritative.
Cut! Goin’ again, Eddie. A BELL sounds. The CREW rustles in the shadows.
Sorry, Sam. Sorry, everybody. Of course, the one day the author’s among us. Trumbo sits nearby, in a bespoke suit, calmly smoking. Robinson settles in a canvas chair with his name on the b
(as he glides past to talk to the CAMERAMAN) “Among us.” Sure ain’t one of us.
(keeping it light) What’s the brilliant line, Trumbo? (CONTINUED)
“If we don’t fight these guys, sure, maybe you get that long, happy life we all want.”
Then what is it you’ve got me fighting for again?
“Peace on Earth, good will toward men.” Nearby, Wood SNORTS. Yeah, right.
You can’t do that, this is America.
How about sex and money?
There you go, two things we all love. None of your little sermons on citizenship.

A flat half-acre dominated by a massive pool that GLOWS w a hundred floating candles. A PARTY where: - MEN are in black tie, WOMEN in gowns, everyone smokes, everyone drinks. Different time, different world. - There’s MUSIC from a live BIG BAND. VOICES overlap and compete as we snag snippets:
“,.-I don’t love it but Zanuck does...”
“,..make the Indians the good guys, that’s the twist...”
“Now the actors want to go on strike. Who’s next? Lassie?” CLEO TRUMBO, 30s, hovers at the edge of a GROUP OF WOMEN about her age. (CONTINUED)

She’s beautiful, observant, sensitive, often silent, as s is here, excusing herself with a warm smile to look for someone at the party, passing by -- A GROUP OF MEN. Louder, more boisterous. Within that grou Edward G. Robinson.

(in mid-sentence) .+.Still doing reshoots, what else? Luckily, Mayer lined up the A Team, Sam Wood to shoot, Dalton Trumbo for rewrites, so, fingers crossed... From across the lawn, TWO MALE VOICES suddenly RISE, so w hear before we see:
...desus, Trumbo, a goddamn six- month strike, for what?

(dryly) Well, I think... money. Cleo Trumbo turns to that second VOICE with minor dread a as she does, she and Robinson clock one another with the thought: Jesus, here we go... As they both zero in on: Director Sam Wood, more than a little drunk.
Laugh it up. I had no crew! I couldn’t work -- (shouting at Trumbo) -- you wouldn't work, God forbid you cross a picket line. For set builders. What do set builders have to do with writing?

What writers write, builders build. What they build, you film. You make all the money you possibly can, so do I, why shouldn’t they? And why can’t we help them? In the long run, it’s better for everyone - (CONTINUED)
-- said the Swimming Pool Soviet.

(calmly) Sam. You won. The strike’s over, the union’s history. We've all gone back to being good little worker bees making sweet movie honey and you -- (now, just a little sharp) -- might just try being a gracious winner. That last comes with a gentle poke into Wood’s lapel from Trumbo’s fingers, which hold his cigarette. Wood does not appreciate the jab or the accompanying smoke in his face.
It’s never over with you people -- strike, after strike, after strike!
Wood is SHOUTING now. Among the Guests: HEADS turn... SMI falter... CONVERSATIONS stop.
Y'know what? I’m going on strike -- against people WHO GO ON STRIKE!
And I won’t cross your picket line, either. Wood might just shove Trumbo now, he’s so angry, but -- -- suddenly, Robinson is there to get Wood’s arm in a friendly grasp.

(with jovial aplomb) Sam, Sam, Sam, we've got to talk about those scenes tomorrow, disaster, who the hell wrote that crap? (a wink at Trumbo, steering Wood away) But first, may I have this dance...? At the same time, Cleo takes her husband’s hand and moves in the opposite direction. (CONTINUED)
Having fun?

Eternally. They kiss and move to the bar, passing -- -- a tall, broad MAN of 39 who eyes Trumbo the way a west sheriff would a gunfighter. We don’t know it yet, but: This is JOHN WAYNE. And as his eyes follow the Trumbos, he meets the gaze of WOMAN. Late middle years, trim, striking, grand yet folks always in a stylish hat. Wayne and she share a moment of silent understanding. We don’t know it yet, but: This is HEDDA HOPPER.
Actual black & white documentary footage of a waving WINS CHURCHILL, grimly addressing an assembly:

Nobody knows what Soviet Russia intends to do. An Iron Curtain has descended across the continent. The newsreel CUTS TO a cartoon map of Europe and Asia as animated red Iron Curtain drops, enclosing Soviet Russia.

The front line in a new kind of war. A Cold War! SHOTS of Russian military might: ARMIES march, FIGHTERS launch, TANKS roll. NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) The enemy -- Communists! BACK TO the cartoon map as the Iron Curtain BECOMES a ser of red tentacles -- NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) Their goal -- world domination! (CONTINUED)
-- and those tentacles slither across Europe and Asia, heading for the United States.

MEN in ties, WOMEN in dresses, KIDS in their Sunday best. And among them WE FIND Dalton Trumbo with his family: daughter NIKI, 8, son CHRIS, 6, Cleo, and in her lap, the youngest, MITZI, 2, all munching and sipping movie treats watching --

As it CUTS TO A SHOT OF the Hollywood sign -- NEWSREEL NARRATOR (CONT’D) Dateline: Hollywood. The offices of former film starlet, now top columnist, Hedda Hopper. -- then DISSOLVES TO A SHOT of a newspaper column under t aerodynamically lettered byline, HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD Next to the text, Hedda Hopper. As she begins to speak fr inside her column:
(to camera) Greetings from our film capital, where all is sun and fun. Or is it?

Grouped together a bit awkwardly in bright midday sun: HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) See the famous faces here? Danny Kaye, Humphrey Bogart, his dishy bride, Lauren Bacall, their good friend, film director John Huston, and many others... CLOSE-UPS (ARCHIVAL) of these FAMOUS FACES, plus a few LE WELL-KNOWN. HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) ...all of whom have declared solidarity with film crews picketing for higher wages. In walk-outs that quickly turned violent. (CONTINUED)
STUDIOS that indeed turn violent: POLICE CLUB THE STRIKER

head_text.subj: ATTACK DOGS MAUL, FIRE HOSES SPRAY --

text: HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Because these strikes were in fact the work of dangerous radicals. A NEW CLOSE-UP (TO BE SHOT) -- SOMEONE standing on an app box, addressing a peaceful line of studio PICKETERS: It’s Dalton Trumbo, his black & white face 40 feet high:
.--this is what angers and frightens the studios!

The Trumbo family is silently stunned. Trumbo’s own jaw slackens just a bit at the surreal sight of himself up on screen, then he quickly regains his composure. But his oldest child can’t help herself --
Dad, is that you? He nods curtly, pats her arm and the tiny, color, real Tr down here watches:
Delivering this searing union rallying cry to the assembl among whom we glimpse an APPLAUDING Edward G. Robinson:

We’ve discovered where our true power lies! Builders, cameramen, painters, drivers, writers, actors, directors! We are a single, indivisible brotherhood of workers. Bargain with a few of us, you bargain with all of us! Threaten one, you threaten us all and it’s war! We are many but from this day forward -- we are one! The Picketers and Movie Stars UP ON SCREEN begin to CHEER Trumbo as --
This is writer Dalton Trumbo. Who is... (CONTINUED)
A new CLOSE-UP of Hedda Hopper in her office:
.--like many of those strikers -- and their supporters -- a registered Communist.
As daughter looks at father, surprised -- is that true? Trumbo doesn’t meet her questioning gaze, just smokes and stoically takes in:
Dwarfing him:

Which is why we must know: Who exactly was behind that walk-out... and why? The scene now CUTS TO various CONGRESSMEN, INVESTIGATORS AIDES mounting the stairs of the U.S. Capitol. HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Our elected leaders will find out. The CAMERA SINGLES OUT a bald, fifty-ish New Jerseyite -- HEDDA HOPPER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Congressman J. Parnell Thomas and his House Un-American Activities Committee.

Communism is not some faraway threat; its most dangerous agents are here, controlling the airwaves and movie screens, taking over its employees and their unions. They need to be identified as the enemies they are.
The five Trumbos stream out with the audience. When suddenly --

head_text.subj: A YOUNG FATHER WITH HIS KIDS

text: Hey, that you in the newsreel...? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 11.
It was, yes -- The Father FLINGS Coke into Trumbo’s face, SPLATTERING hi
Traitor -- -- terrifying Cleo and the kids before taking off.
(dripping, calm) No harm done, everybody okay?
Mountain, meadow and sky dwarf this fine spread. Trumbo walks along the fence while Niki rides a horse next to hi
So, are you a Communist?
I am.
Is it against the law?
It is not.
That lady with the big hat said you're a “dangerous radical.” Are you?
Radical, maybe. Dangerous, only to men who fling Cokes.
You don’t want to overthrow the government?
No, we have a good government. But anything good can be better, don’t you think?
Is Mom a Communist? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 12.
No.
Am I?
Let's give you the official test. Mom packs your favorite lunch...
Salami.
.»..and you see someone at school with no lunch -- what do you do?
Share?
You don’t tell them to get a job?
(aware she’s being teased) No.
Offer a loan at six percent?
Dad.
Then just ignore them.
No. He studies his oldest daughter with great affection.

Well, well. You little Commie. INT. EDWARD G. ROBINSON’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Elegant, tasteful, its walls glowing colorfully with: Six spotlit French Impressionist paintings. Seated under a Renoir, Trumbo is debating with Robinson and a small gathering of DIRECTORS, PRODUCERS, ACTORS and WRITERS.
(CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 13.
Trumbo, as usual, you only make sense to you. Let ‘em call you a Communist, me a Democrat -- both legitimate parties, yours is just meaner and duller but nothing illegal about any of it.
Yet.
Hunter, tell your friend to dial down the paranoia and have a drink. This to screenwriter IAN McLELLAN HUNTER, 32, quick mind, eyes, sharp wit, always puffing on a pipe:
I don’t think he’s being paranoid enough.
Not you, too. Trumbo pulls several booklets of mimeoed paper from a val
I’ve drawn up a little pamphlet. (passing them out) Subject: “Congress Unaware of Little Thing Called First Amendment.”
They're aware... Everyone turns to the man saying:
...they just don’t give a shit. ARLEN HIRD is 40s, caustic, dyspeptic; the BUTLER offerin him a canape, which he waves off --
All they care about is this nice, new war of theirs -- these guys love war -- and this is a great one, scary, vague and expensive. Anybody for it’s a hero, anybody against it’s a traitor. (CONTINUED)
And anybody who thinks it’s about movies is an idiot. Which is why I’m going to go have a chat with the other side.
You don’t mean the Alliance.
I do. A CHORUS of disbelieving MOANS and startled LAUGHS.
Are you out of your mind -- ?
They're actors, writers, directors, just like us --
They're Nazis, they’re just too cheap to buy the uniforms --
They invited Congress out here --
(to the room at large) And are they all Sam Wood and Hedda Hopper? Let’s not demonize people we don’t really know.
Go for it. Be fun. ‘Cause ya know who you’re gonna be talkin’ to?
I wanna say one thing about a place I love. No, not Hollywood... And WE REVEAL WE’RE --
.+.I like Hollywood... Alone on stage, John Wayne, six-feet, four inches of bass voiced movie icon. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 15.
JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) -.-but I love America! As WE REVEAL a sign near the stage announcing this is:

head_text.subj: THE MOTION PICTURE ALLIANCE FOR THE PRESERVATION

text: WE SEE the HUGE CROWD of movie pros, from below-the-line to above-the-line stars, all CHEERING and APPLAUDING Wayn JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) And when we talk about America I’m talking about freedom! The kinda freedom we just fought a world war to save! You wanna be a Commie, go be a Commie... but some friends of mine in Washington think you got some questions to answer!

head_text.subj: AT THE BACK OF THE ROOM

text: Trumbo, Hird, Hunter and Edward G. Robinson all stand, studying Wayne, awed and disturbed by his power.
I never knew he was this good.
‘Cause he’s not acting, that’s him.
Wayne’s voice RISES with the MOB’S CHEERS.
Still wanna be a Commie? Be a Commie! In Russia! But off ya go 'n’ enjoy the Bolshoi Ballet!
Trumbo, Hird, Robinson and Hunter offer copies of Trumbo’ pamphlet to THOSE who ignore or shoot them dirty looks. O put on their hats and throw smug smiles. Including --
(as he accepts a pamphlet) Do svidaniya. Russian for “goodbye,” as he tears it to shreds. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 16.
This? Is a nightmare.
If it were, I'd be in bed. An elegantly turned out, in-the-flesh Hedda Hopper approaches.
Hello, Dalton.
Hedda, here you are, of course. Good evening to you.
Eddie, darling.
Hedda. New hat?
Daily, dear, daily. (to Trumbo) Been to the movies lately? (before he can answer) Duke! John Wayne has crossed the room with IATSE Union Leader R BREWER, 40, jowly, jovial and shrewd.
Wasn’t he? Mag. Nificent.
Just sayin’ what needs sayin’. (then) Hiya, Eddie.
Duke.
Hear you ‘n’ your pals got a “pamphlet.” Any takers?
Not yet... (CONTINUED)
(offers one to Wayne) Would you like one? We’re Communists.
(shrugs) He’s a writer.
(to Robinson) Ya won’t get any takers. Not here.

Why not? Wayne now turns and regards an affable Trumbo. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) All it says is, Congress has no right to investigate how we vote, where we pray, what we think, say or make movies about. (holds out the pamphlet) Hello, I’m Dalton Trumbo.
(takes the pamphlet) Congress has the right to go after anything they think is a threat.
We disagree. That’s the point -- we both have the right to be wrong. A LOOSE, CURIOUS GROUP has begun to gather, sensing troub
You wanna talk about rights, first show me whose side you're on. Russia’s no friend, not anymore. You better wake up. (then) ‘Cause it’s a new day. A new day.
And?
Maybe it’s not for your kind.
My kind, what kind is that? (CONTINUED)
Kind that has no idea why we just won a war. Wayne crumples Trumbo’s pamphlet, tosses it and starts of

That’s the second time you’ve brought that up. I was a war correspondent in Okinawa -- (to Hedda now) -- your son was stationed in the Philippines -- (re: Robinson) -- Eddie was in Europe with the Office of War Information -- (back to Wayne) -- where’d you serve again?
(stops, turns) You tryin’ to say something?
No, Duke, he wasn’t --
Stay out of it, Eddie --

(right in Wayne’s face) If you’re gonna talk about World War Two like you personally won it, let’s be clear where you were stationed -- on a film set, shooting blanks, wearing makeup and if you’re going to hit me, I'd like to take my glasses off. Wayne could belt him but camera FLASHBULBS POP.
Duke, let’s get outta here... He urges the apoplectic Wayne to a doorway.
Thank you, Dalton. My next column just wrote itself. She exits. Robinson, Hird and Hunter just stare at Trumbo (CONTINUED)
(happy as a clam) That was... I don’t even know what to...

Yes, good thing you don’t want to demonize anybody or that could’ve been awkward. EXT. MGM STUDIOS —- DAY Walking with Robinson, Trumbo crosses the gleaming, BUSY dream factory at the height of its productivity, stops at newsstand to buy cigarettes and is confronted by a strang and awful sight: The face of Hedda Hopper on the July 28, 1947 cover of TI magazine, the copies all hung in a line, creating two doz identical Heddas. Trumbo is quietly amused, Robinson slightly horrified.

Good God. (reaches for a copy) Trumbo, you pick your enemies the way you live -- only the best will do. INT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY LOUIS B. MAYER, 60, warm-hearted, cold-blooded studio president, beams affectionately at Trumbo.

Your next deal’s gonna make you the highest-paid writer in Hollywood, which’'1l make you the highest-paid writer in the world. BUDDY ROSS, early 30s, a young, go-getter producer, sits to the side, eyes darting anxiously between the studio president and the writer.
You earned it. You don’t just write happy endings, you actually believe them.
That’s what the people pay to see, that’s why you belong here at MGM, right, L.B.? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 20.
Look, I hate to make the wooing too easy for you but: Where do I sign?

Just one thing. If you’re going to work for me... (unfolds a newspaper) ...I never, ever want to see anything like this... HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD column: a photo of Dalton Trumbo under the headline, “OUR OWN RED MENACE.”
..-again. Trumbo and Mayer lock eyes. Buddy is frozen silent.
You won’t. I promise. Mayer nods, satisfied. Buddy could kiss Trumbo. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Just stop reading Hedda Hopper. Off Mayer's fury and Buddy’s panic --

Overlooking their lake. Trumbo stands at a hot grill, flipping filet of trout, holding court for his family; Hunter, his WIFE and CHILDREN; Robinson and his WIFE; Bud Ross and a GLAMOROUS INGENUE GIRLFRIEND.
(to Cleo) Mom, please...?
(to Niki) Not now, honey.
So what'd L.B. say then?
Jesus, don’t, I haven’t eaten since. My job’s not hard enough?
Your job’s not hard at all. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 21.
You think getting Mayer to sign you after those headlines was easy? You have a record-breaking, three- year contract -- to make shit up. You’re welcome.
C'mon, Mom!
A solitary black sedan churns up a plume of dust.
Trumbo and the other adults LAUGH and drink away a dazzli summer afternoon.
(to Robinson) She really can! Ask her!
(chuckling) Cleo? Is this true?
I... had a very unusual mother.
Which means “Stage Mother.” He picks up a glass, a twinkle in his eye.

(knows what’s coming, laughs, embarrassed) Trumbo, no... He hands Niki the glass, who tosses it to Cleo, which she catches easily, then another, which she catches in her ot hand, beginning to lightly JUGGLE the two, causing the children to finally SQUEAL with delight as --
-- that black sedan takes a gravel-popping turn and --  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 22.
-- Robinson and his Wife stare in amazement, watching Cle expertly JUGGLE two glasses, flipping and catching one be her back as Trumbo beams.
The misspent youth of a child acrobat.
My God, how long were you in show business?
(juggling away) Till I was 15. And it was more “show-forced-labor.” Niki tosses her mother a third glass, which Cleo catches, pinwheeling all three easily.
She never drops one, ever.
Mom had a little saying. “Drop it, you lose your next meal.”
(to Robinson) And “Mom” wasn’t kidding. Woman was a Dickensian harridan.
(laughs) No one even knows what that means.
The black sedan closes in --

-- as Cleo does over-hand grabs, then switches to a circu pattern, the spool of tumblers catching sunlight in dazzl prisms. AND THROUGH CLEO’S GLASSY WHIRL OF COLOR - WE SEE THAT SE Pull to a stop and Trumbo sees THREE MEN in suits get out  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 23.
Family and friends watching, Trumbo greets the three men, among whom we recognize: HUAC Investigator Robert Stripli
Mr. Dalton Trumbo? Stripling hands Trumbo a pink document.
Congressman J. Parnell Thomas stands before REPORTERS:
Nineteen subpoenas have been issued to those we believe have knowledge of the ongoing Communist threat in Hollywood. This announcement is greeted with a resounding... pause.
Uh, what kind of threat is that?
A conspiracy to corrupt democratic values and bring about the overthrow of this nation.
Using... movies. The CHUCKLING Reporters clearly think this is horseshit.
Any movie in particular or...?
(cutting him off) Movies are the most powerful form of influence ever created and they are infested with hidden traitors who will be dragged into the light, for all to see and all to judge.
HEDDA HOPPER’S HOLLYWOOD NEWSREEL Her talking face again appears alongside her column. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 24.
(to camera) We travel now...
And actual newsreel footage in black & white of the Capit packed with POLITICIANS, EXECUTIVES and STARS.

.-.to Washington, D.C., where battle lines are drawn. On one side, Communist subversives. On the other, studio heads, labor leaders and some of our brightest stars. And in actual footage from his testimony that day, RONALD REAGAN, 36, handsome and measured, cooperates with Robert Stripling before a PACKED HOUSE.
Your profession, Mr. Reagan?
Motion picture actor.
And you are currently the president of the Screen Actors Guild?
Yes, sir.
Has it been reported to you that certain members of the guild were Communists?
Yes, sir, I have heard different discussions of some of them as Communists.
More actual news footage -- CONGRESSMAN RICHARD M. NIXON California), 34. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 25.
Do you believe that the motion picture industry is doing everything it can to rid itself of subversive, Un-American influences? Then answering, in testimony we recreate in matching blac white --
No! The Communists are everywhere! They report directly to Moscow! Then --
Enough is enough! The Communists have to go!
What we’re about to do...

...won’t make us too popular. Trumbo leads a small strategy session with Robert Kenny, Arlen Hird and a HALF-DOZEN of the SUBPOENAED 19 and -- -- Niki, in a corner, quietly taking everything in. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Our support’s not only going to vanish, we’re going to get attacked by our own.
Okay, we get slandered, then what?
You testify and answer every question they ask, in your own way.
So don’t tell ‘em shit.
Beautifully put. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 26.
In her corner, Niki smiles.
Of the nineteen forced to appear, only ten were called to the stand. The Hollywood Nineteen wait to be called to testify.
Dubbed “The Hollywood Ten,” they refused to answer every question about their Communist ties.
You know what that’s called?
Contempt of Congress. Beat. The room is silent, Niki transfixed. Then --
Maybe I’m missing something, ‘cause all I’m seein’ here is jail.
As Trumbo is sworn in, there’s a BLINDING CAMERA FLASH an Congress, the crowds and Trumbo all BURST INTO FULL COLOR
Mr. Trumbo, I will ask various questions, all of which can be answered yes or no.

I shall answer yes or no if I please to. Many questions can only be answered yes or no by a moron or a slave. As the caucus room FLUTTERS with DISBELIEVING MOANS, supportive LAUGHTER and a few nasty BOOS, WE FIND -- (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 27.
Cleo Trumbo, in the gallery, serenely unsurprised by her husband’s insolence.
No one can beat Congress in Congress. The only place to do that’s in court --
-- in front of a judge who'll probably hate Commies and rule against us --
-- in a lower court, yes, we'll likely lose but on appeal...
...-it’ll work. The Supreme Court is a five to four liberal majority. They think the Committee's unconstitutional, they want it killed and we’re gonna hand them the case to do it.
Great. Best of luck. I’m out. And suddenly, Hird is on his feet and gone.

Mitzi SPLASHES in the water with Chris as Cleo aims a lar professional camera at them and snaps pictures. Arlen Hird walks to a nearby tree, leans against it and s a cigarette into his mouth. Trumbo walks up.
(sighs, beat) Look, I can’t afford what you’re talkin’ about... Supreme Court, legal fees. My wife, it’s never been great, but I raid our savings for this? She’s gone, with both boys. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 28.
I’ll cover you. Expenses, travel, legal fees... Hird is shocked by Trumbo’s casual generosity.
You don’t even like me.
I like you fine, you don’t like me.
Also, I don’t trust you.
I'd say “go on,” but I’m afraid you will.
Look. I know what I am, okay? I want this country to be a whole new... everything. Top to bottom. And if I get what I want? Nobody gets their own lake.
Seems a little grim.

For you, yeah. But not the guys who built all this... (the ranch, the lake) .-.for you, their families, friends. Which, remember, is kind of the point. Them, not you. I mean, if I’m wrong here, tell me, but ever since I’ve known you, you talk like a radical, live like a rich guy --
True.

-- ‘'n’ I don’t think if it gets right down to it, you're willing to lose all this just to do what’s right. Radical would, rich guy? I don’t think so. Trumbo watches his family in the sparkling light of his l (CONTINUED)

Am I “willing.” Hm. (beat) Well. I hate martyrs and will not fight a lost cause, so you're right, I’m not willing to lose it all -- I’m willing to risk it. That's why being the radical and the rich guy is the perfect combination. The radical may fight
with the purity of Jesus... but the rich guy wins with the cunning of Satan.
Y'know, the thing is, really? You’re wrong about almost everything and you never shut up.
No, no, no, no -- }
Still in glorious color that reveals the face of Congress Thomas to be red as a blister as he POUNDS his gavel --
-- no, no, no, no, no, no! -- like a four year old throwing a tantrum. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist party?
Mr. Stripling, may I read a statement?
No.
May I present my writing?
No.
May I -- ? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 30.
No, no, no! Answer the question!
Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist Party?
Have I been accused of a crime? If so, what is it and where is your evidence?
You’re not asking the questions!
Well, I was.
The witness will answer.
I see. And then what would you like? My voting record, union membership, religion?
Answer the question!
You believe this Committee has the right to compel testimony, indict opinion --
Typical Communist tactics!
-- criminalize thought -- but that right does not exist and the day it does, God help us all.
-- Arlen Hird is now on the stand.
Are you now or have you ever been a member of the Communist party? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 31.
Congressman, first I need to call my doctor.
Your doctor? I don’t un --

To see if he can surgically remove my conscience. EXPLOSIVE LAUGHTER no amount of GAVELLING by Thomas can s Trumbo sits beside Cleo in the gallery, delighted and surprised. And our HEARING MONTAGE ENDS.
Trumbo and Hird walk as Hird begins to COUGH, can’t stop.
What? What is it?
Cancer.
Jesus. How long’ve you known?
Couple months.
Months? Are you being treated -- ?
I don’t like the options. It’s lung cancer. Bad if they operate, bad if they don’t.
Is there anything I can do?
No! No. It’s cancer, Jesus. (then) Yes. Make sure this fuckin’ plan of yours works.
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 32.

THE NEW YORK TIMES: “’HOLLYWOOD 10’ CHARGED WITH CONTEMPT CONGRESS” Under that, a group photo of The Hollywood Ten, PUSHING I the grainy faces of Hird and Trumbo. INT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY Other faces, in framed photos on a wall: CLARK GABLE, JUD GARLAND, FRED ASTAIRE, more. Being studied by Hedda Hoppe Mayer enters, sees Hedda is focused on a group photo with row of SILENT STARS where, squeezed between RAMON NAVARRO GRETA GARBO, a younger Hedda stands alongside a boyish Ma
Look at us. God, we thought we knew everything...
We did.

Not me. (then) I didn’t know how much I loved it all, till I hit a certain birthday and the parts started drying up. I remember thinking, when you love something and it stops loving you back, what do you do...?
You fight.
That’s a man’s answer. (he concedes, waits) You love it more. Till it surrenders.
Well. You never left MGM. Or my heart. How’s your boy? Still in the Navy?
First lieutenant.
You raised a real hero. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 33.
Which is why I’d like to tell him we're doing as much for this country as he is. (then) Are we?
It’s complicated. Trumbo, the others, all have contracts...
You helped build this business, so did I, we’re not gonna watch these pissants defile it --
I’m running a studio here, you think I love every person on my payroll? Grow up.

Then how about I make crystal clear to my thirty-five million readers who runs Hollywood and won’t fire these traitors? How about I name names, real names? Like yours, Lazar Meir; or Jack Warner, Jacob Varner; Sam Goldwyn, Schmuel Gelbfisz --
You watch what you say to me --
No, you watch! This isn’t 1920! I’m not your STARLET, you don’t tell me what to do! Never, ever, ever, ever, EVER AGAIN!
Enough, Hedda --

Forty years ago, you're starving in some shtetl, the greatest country on Earth takes you in, gives you wealth, power and the second we need you, you do nothing! (then) Just what my readers expect from a business run by kikes.
(CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 34.
Get out. She sits. Takes a cigarette out of her case. Lights it. She blows a wall of smoke between them.

Now listen, L.B. I’m fond of you. Some of my happiest years were spent on this lot. (then) Not in your office, of course, you always trying to fuck me on the couch, me maintaining my virtue. Barely. (lightly) But... times change. Now I’1l happily fuck you.
EXT. MGM STUDIOS - LOUIS B. MAYER’S OFFICE - DAY Black & white NEWSREEL, created by us, of Mayer, flanked the other studio heads, reading a press statement to camera:

Forthwith, all studios unanimously agree to discharge the Hollywood Ten. Without compensation. Effective immediately. (then) Further, no studio will ever employ a member of the Communist Party or anyone refusing to cooperate in our mighty struggle against this terrible new menace. INT. HEDDA HOPPER’S OFFICE - DAY Hedda reads her copy into a large microphone.

He’s been loved by film fans for almost twenty years. But have you noticed? He hasn’t been on-screen much lately. Bad box office? No. Bad politics. Bad news indeed. For Mr. Edward G. Robinson. INT. EDWARD G. ROBINSON’S MANSION - LIVING ROOM - DAY Robinson addresses a small GROUP, many of whom would rath not be here. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 35.
The Hollywood Ten’s going to court for all of us. It’1ll be long, expensive. So please, give as much as you can to the defense fund.
The gathering has thinned. Trumbo studies Robinson's Impressionist paintings. Robinson wanders over with Cleo.
This little gathering doesn’t quite have the zip and zing of yesteryear, does it?
Where’re all the liberals all of a sudden?
At their lawyers’. Or psychiatrists’.
Likely both. Anyway... (hands Trumbo a check) ...for the defense fund.
(hesitates) You working again?
Eh. It’s a little slow. (to Trumbo) I'll be fine, kid, take it. Trumbo does, reluctantly, then:
You sold one. Cleo looks at the wall and sees a discolored space. There were six paintings; now only five.
The Renoir. I got a good price. Trumbo is moved beyond words -- a rare occurrence. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 36.
Eddie, I... (overcome ) ---well... I...
What he’s trying to say is, he loves you.
(to Cleo) I love him, too, the warty son of a bitch. (then, to Trumbo) Oh and I got a great offer on the Monet, if you want to bribe the jury.
As the JURY FOREMAN reads:

In the matter of the United States versus Dalton Trumbo... Trumbo stands at the bar, next to attorney Robert Kenny. JURY FOREMAN (CONT’D) ...we find the defendant guilty of contempt of Congress. He was ready for this, but the reality hits hard. His eye betray just a flicker of agony. Then, aware of all the stares, his battler’s armored visage returns.
Trumbo and Kenny exit the courtroom in a river of COURT F
I have total contempt for Congress, I just thought a jury’d see why.
Trumbo and Kenny fight their way through the clinging PRE (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 37.
(to Reporters) The Supreme Court will drop kick this verdict into speeding traffic and end the most shameful chapter of Congressional history I ever want to live through.
Trumbo and Kenny.
How're you doing for money?
Broke as a bankrupt’s bastard. Why?
You owe me thirty-thousand dollars. The appeal’s gonna be twice that.
Well, better get to work.
Doing what?
Trumbo writes furiously on his typewriter. The sounds of LAUGHTER pierce his CLATTER. He looks up at the window, t rises, crossing to it.
Cleo on the driveway, where a ping-pong table’s been set She’s teaching Niki, 4-year-old Mitzi and Chris how to pl the game. There is much GIGGLING amid the missed shots.
Silently separated from his family by the sheet of glass. Then he has to let the curtain drop back across the windo Back to it.
One light on. Trumbo’s study.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 38.
Arlen Hird lies in a weakened, post-surgery stupor. His e open and he sees Trumbo setting down some flowers.
How are you?
Breathin’. With one lung. Which is half as good as two. How bad’re things out there?
Everybody envies you. Hird looks around the pleasant, private room.
Why not. Got the best room in the joint. You oughta know, you paid for it. (then, woozy) Thanks. By the way. Trumbo smiles at Hird, whose eyes flutter shut.
Mayer's a dinosaur... Over the streamlined entrance, a steel-sculpted banner: R INTERNATIONAL PICTURES.
...-they all are, extinct and don’t even know it. INT. ROSS INTERNATIONAL - BUDDY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Enormous and pristine.
Let’s see now, to, uh... Buddy, Trumbo and other MOVIE-INDUSTRY COMPATRIOTS raise champagne glasses in the winter of 1948. (CONTINUED)

TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 39. BUDDY ROSS (CONT’D) .»..to no more MGM, no more Mayer, I am strictly independent, got cans of film, wads of Wall Street dough and my favorite boss -- me! (all CHUCKLE, CLINK, sip, then to Trumbo) And you, you crazy son of a bitch, are gonna write all my movies, once this Washington crap clears up. A throat is CLEARED. Trumbo is a bit more pensive than we seen him.
And how’ll that happen?
Hey. I’m not political. Thank Jesus. But if they called me in, accused me? I’d just say, yep, did it, sorry, didn’t mean it. Trumbo nods, willing to move on. But somehow just can’t h himself.
(evenly) So Congress asks, “Are you now or have you ever been a Democrat...?”
“I am... and God, I just feel awful about it, never again...”
But now they want the names of other Democrats. (points at random MEN) Bill... Stan... Earl... Nat.
Then I say go to hell.

Really. And how many banks fund enemies of the state? Your money's gone. Unless you give the names of your friends here. They’1ll never work again. But it’s the only way you ever will. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 40.
We’re all friends here, we all know each other... we hope. What would you do, Buddy? Buddy stares, chilled. Silence. Then --
Piss on the best day of a guy’s life! Only you! BIG LAUGHS all around. But from those four men Trumbo singled out, nervous ones. And from Trumbo, not so much a smile.
Trumbo hard at the keys, surrounded by full ashtrays, pil of typescript and a half-empty scotch bottle. He pauses t shift in his seat and twist his aching back.
He lies on the couch, scotch on his chest, pillow under h back, scribbling on typed copy, still in some pain. Niki, almost _11 now, walks in wearing her nightgown.
Morning, Nikola.
I thought you weren’t allowed to write anymore.
No. Just can’t put my name on it or get paid.
How’s that work?
Niki eats a sundae, watching Trumbo and Hunter as the lat thumbs a dog-eared screenplay with scribbles on many page and bold handwriting on the cover.
Well?
(the script) It's funny, breezy, romantic. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 41.
(then, sarcastically) Who the hell wrote it?
You did, old boy. Stick your name on my labor, hand it in to your studio and --
Look, it’s just dumb luck I wasn’t subpoenaed. The hearings’re gonna start up again soon, I’m gonna get called and canned...
Then quick, lad, let’s sell this little beauty and split the take, fifty-fifty.
Ridiculous. I’11 take ten percent.
You'll take twenty. No, thirty. That's my final offer.
You are the worst businessman, ever. (then) I hate the title.
Me too. She gets a sharp look from her father that drives her bac her ice cream.
I mean, The Princess and the Peasant... (scribbling on the cover) .»».sounds like a puppet show.
(shrugs) Change it.
I did. (CONTINUED)
He slides the script across the table to Trumbo, its new title atop the cover page’s handwritten notes, in bold fe and circled. Trumbo’s distaste for it is immediate.

Now, who the hell’s going to go see a movie called Roman Holiday? INT. U.S. CAPITOL —- ROTUNDA - DAY Congressman Thomas moves with a small CLUSTER of many of same REPORTERS from Scene 30, all now his acolytes --
.--I’m going to introduce legislation so in the event of national emergency, all Communists will be sent to internment camps...
Does the president support this?

He'd better. Stripling now appears at Thomas’ shoulder, WHISPERS in hi ear as he shows him a sheaf of monetary columns. Both Stripling’s hushed, unheard words and the document’s sheet get Thomas’ full attention. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) (to the Reporters) Excuse me, gentleman. He and Stripling peel off, away from the Reporters. CONGRESSMAN THOMAS (CONT’D) I’ve told you, Bob, these are legitimate, salaried employees from my home state --
What you didn’t tell me is, every one of them is a relative.
Which is completely legal.
Except none of them have paid taxes. (as Thomas tries to explain) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 43.
Don’t say anything else without a lawyer.
Cleo gets out of her car, carrying mail and The L.A. Time She walks past a half-finished addition, abandoned at framing. She scans the front page of the paper.
(suddenly shaken) +. NO... JEFF, their contractor, sun-baked, 30s, has been waiting.
Mrs. Trumbo? Ma’am, I gotta get paid. She looks up, truly at a loss. JEFF THE CONTRACTOR (CONT’D) Please, I got men with families.
Jeff. We owe everyone. But my husband can’t get work. Before Jeff can respond, Trumbo speeds up in his car and skids to a stop and bounds out with two bottles of champa
(ecstatic once again) We're rich!
Trumbo signs a check with a flourish and hands it to Jeff
Thanks. You sure lead exciting lives. Boy. He pockets it as Trumbo reaches for the champagne.
It sold, Cleo, Roman Holiday, Paramount, credited to our dear Hunter and what, what’s the matter?
Justice Rutledge died. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 44,
No, Justice Murphy, last --
And Rutledge. This morning. She hands him the Times. As he reads, she holds him. INT. ROBERT KENNY’S LAW OFFICE - CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY

The two most liberal judges on the Supreme Court... Trumbo, a still-frail Arlen Hird and members of The Ten s solemnly before a heartsick Kenny. ROBERT KENNY (CONT’D) .+-back to back. This is just... He lets it hang in the air. A long, ten-man silence.
Well. I’11 be goddamned if I know what to say.
One upside, anyway.

Our appeal’s gonna be denied. You're all going to prison. INT. ROBERT KENNY’S LAW OFFICE - ELEVATOR - DAY Trumbo helps Hird in. Hird pushes the button, then leans his cane. Both men stare straight ahead as they descend. As sick as Hird is, Trumbo is paler. He looks gutted. The CLANKING descent seems eternal. Then:
I wouldn't change a thing. Not one. Would you? Trumbo considers this carefully before:
Let’s ask each other in a year.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 45.
June, 1950. NO SOUND at first, just MUSIC as Trumbo, Cleo Niki, Chris, 9, and Mitzi, now 5, cross the tarmac to a waiting DC-3 prop passenger plane. Suddenly aware of --
A CROWD gathering at the edge of the light, moving toward them. Then, TWO PEOPLE raise a banner, the words spread o on a sheet between two poles:

head_text.subj: DALTON TRUMBO IS GOING TO JAIL

text: The crowd closes around the surprised Trumbos. Hands are offered and shaken. More signs raised. More PEOPLE cluste Cameras are brought out and --
Slightly embarrassed, is surrounded by family, well-wishe and more huge, handwritten signs bearing his name and pli
Capturing the final, sad moments of Trumbo’s goodbye: - Tiny Mitzi hugs Trumbo. She can’t be pried off. - Trumbo whispers into Chris’ ear:
I’m counting on you. Your mother needs to laugh. Once a day. At least. Deal? Chris nods and refuses to cry. Father and son shake hands - Trumbo hugs Niki. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Don’t be afraid.
I’m not. She's angry at herself for tearing up. Trumbo hands her h silk pocket square. - Trumbo kisses Cleo one last time on the lips. - Trumbo is led off by TWO U.S. MARSHALS. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 46.
- Trumbo is up on the ramp of the plane. A FLASHBULB POPS The moment is FROZEN into an old sepia photograph.
The Trumbo family car rumbles home from the airport.
In the backseat, Niki consoles Mitzi. Up front, Chris rid alongside Cleo, who is driving. Everyone is grieving in their own way. Then --
(suddenly blurting) I was married before. Well, this certainly gets the attention of all the kids.
Your father’s my second husband.
Holy shit.
Niki...
Mom, gimme a break, you can’t just say that and not --
I’m saying it for a reason. When I met your father, I had a boyfriend.
What was his name?
Hal.
Hal. Heh.
Did you love him?
That’s not the point. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 47.
What’d you think of Pop back then?
I couldn’t stand him.
So how’d you end up marrying him?
I was waitressing. He came in for a hamburger, we talked a little, I brought him the check and he proposed.
Seriously? Cleo catches Niki’s look in the rear view, a smile that s that’s Pop.

I said he was crazy but he kept coming back, night after night. Talking and talking. And the tips! On a ninety-cent check, he’d leave ten dollars! After a year, I had over a thousand dollars. I saved every penny, I wasn’t going to let him think he could buy me. But... also... I just, I’d never met anyone like him, ever, I couldn't stop thinking about him. And guess who didn’t like that much?
Hal.
Hal. Who got mad, then jealous, then went and got a wedding license and a judge.
That must’ve made Pop mad.

No. He just asked if I could see myself with Hal in twenty years and I burst into tears -- I couldn’t see myself with him for twenty more minutes. He was big and crude and had all these rules... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 48.
(then) Your father was such a good friend, I'd never had anyone like him in my life... and do you know what he did? Hired a private detective.
Wow.
And found out Hal was already married. All the kids let out LAUGHS and SHOUTS and pound the seat They love seeing this new side of their mother.
Mom, how could you not tell us this before? This is great!
I’m telling you now because when he did all that, your father proved when he believes in something... or someone...
Large, remote, set amid thick green Kentucky forest.
.--it doesn’t matter what anybody else thinks, says or does... INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON —- PRISONER PROCESSING - DAY

.--he will try, fail... Trumbo is naked, along with a GROUP of prisoners who are undergoing a body and cavity search by GUARDS. fTrumbo is stoic. CLEO (POST-LAP) (CONT’D) .--fall down, get up, fall again. But never, ever give up.
So don’t waste your time being mad at the people trying to stop your father. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 49.
(smiles) Feel sorry for them.
On a blazing summer afternoon, Trumbo off-loads 50-pound slabs of frozen beef rib from a truck, balancing one on h shoulder, sweating and moving past TWO PRISON GUARDS.
(mid-story) ...so he files a complaint, says I don’t treat him fair.
Nigger said that?

So warden says I gotta do right. Boy wanna better job? I put him in charge o’ the whole goddamn supply room. ‘Cause I know somethin’ the warden don’t. Nigger can’t read! Finally, Trumbo gets his huge side of beef to the pallet manages to drop it. He stands, soaked, catching his breat There’s a sharp pain in his back. He tries not to let it show.
(laughing) Can’t read, that’s good!
Serve the jig and warden both right, supply gonna be a goddamn mess!

Very much a mess. Reports and records in random piles and sloppy stacks. But also a cool, dark basement relief from the swelter above. A wrung-out Trumbo hands a clipboard to a powerful, sever black man named VIRGIL BROOKS.
Beef’s unloaded. Driver needs a signature. Brooks nods and takes the clipboard. Without really looki he scribbles a line near the bottom of the page. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA

DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Actually, he needs it... here. Trumbo points to the still-blank signature line. signs again. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) If you could use help, I used to be in shipping, at a bakery.
I heard you was a writer.
That, too.
And a Commie. (with a hard look) Fuck is wrong with you people? This is a great country.
Agreed. Well, he tried. Heads out.
You type?
Eighty words a minute.
Bullshit.
Brooks With two fingers, copying off a rule book. Brooks glances his watch and chops the air. Trumbo stops.

Now if only I could read it. (then, off typewriter page) “Protocol as to return of goods: There shall be triplicate copies of form 14-A filed with Supply, Shipping and office of the warden.” Trumbo looks up at Brooks, surprised. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 51.

You think you gonna teach me the alphabet so I shake your hand all grateful ‘n’ say, “Thankee Missuh Trumbo, you done changed mah life, suh, I never fuhgit you.” (then) This ain’t no movie and I ain’t Mr. Bojangles. I got twenty years for killin’ a white man tried to rob my bar, I did it and I’d do it again. Look down on me and I will fuck you up like you never been fucked up in your whole bullshit Beverly Hills life. I’m here to build my time and get paroled, you wanna help make that happen? Brooks hefts a box of files onto the desk with a THUD.

Welcome to fuckin’ Supply, comrade. INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON —- PRISONER DORM - NIGHT 1951. One of the few prisoners still awake, Trumbo sits o his cot in a single cone of light, scribbling on a pad.
(starting a letter) Dear Cleo. INT. LAZY-T RANCH - CLEO’S DARK ROOM - DAY

I don’t count the days or hours. I count the seconds. She switches the red light off and opens the shades. Summ sun REVEALS developing equipment and dozens of photos hun dry. All of the children: fishing, on horseback, playing tag, sitting for a group portrait.

Sometimes I think I’ll die of boredom. Other times, fear. As she inspects each critically, she passes something we don’t expect: a boxer’s speed bag hanging from the ceilin which she gives a single, light WHACK without looking.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 52.
Immaculately organized now.
Not of this place. Trumbo sits, dutifully typing at top speed.
So far... Prison Guard 1 enters, shocked at the crispness of the ro

...its challenges are all surmountable. Augmented by days of lovely boredom, so flat and calm in the wake of all that churning, ugly, luckless battle. -- and the report Brooks writes with a fuck-you smile.
No, my fear is for what will happen...
Cleo is playing a furious game of ping-pong against both Chris and Mitzi --
...-when I get out. To our family... -- while Niki sits nearby, absorbed in a copy of the Dail Worker, with its headline: “NEW COMMUNIST HOLLYWOOD HEARI BEGIN.”
.«..and our country. INT. ASHLAND FEDERAL PRISON - MESS —- DAY

Not all the national news is worrisome. Some reminds me that what the imagination can’t conjure, reality delivers with a shrug. Nearly deserted but for Trumbo as he enters with a sheaf reports, crossing past a lone figure mopping the floor: (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 53.
Congressman J. Parnell Thomas, wearing a prison uniform identical to Trumbo’s. He stops mopping. Trumbo pauses in doorway. The two men regard one another.

And reality has delivered, in all its beatific wonder, to the federal penal system, former Congressman and head of HUAC, J. Parnell Thomas. Convicted of tax evasion. Thomas goes back to work. Trumbo’s eyes linger on Thomas the former inquisitor dips his mop then swabs the floor.
Proving the truism... Trumbo deposits his sheaf on a table top and exits.
“,..Character is destiny.”
On a sunny morning, her three children eating breakfast around her, Cleo finishes this letter.

Yet in all this, I know I’m the luckiest unlucky man ever to live... because you and the children warm, feed, clothe, pacify and rejuvenate me, by never leaving my heart. Love, Prisoner Number 7551. She touches the paper tenderly, gets up and moves to shoeboxes that overflow with Trumbo letters, adding this
All chairs face a screen as Trumbo and SEVERAL HUNDRED PRISONERS and GUARDS watch a war movie.
Plays a gung-ho soldier, barking orders amid backlot GUNF
Trumbo smokes and watches. Sitting next to him, Virgil Brooks is totally caught up in the war drama.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 54.
Trumbo, Brooks, Prisoners and Guards walk back to the dor
You know John Wayne?
I do.
What’s he like?
You'd love each other.
It was, in fact, an enormous, brown, stucco hat.
Near the front door, the MAITRE D’ slides Hedda’s coat on
‘Scuse me? Are you Hedda Hopper? She turns and sees a YOUNG ENLISTED MAN in an army unifor awkward, nervous, respectful, whose empty right sleeve is pinned up. He’s lost an arm.
I -- yes, hello, how do you -- ? She holds out her right hand, is instantly mortified, but Enlisted Man clasps her right with his left.

I don’t mean to bother you, I’m here with my cousin, he’s a gaffer at Columbia? Thought he’d treat me to the big time. I read you a lot, all the guys do. Not just the showbiz stuff. You get what’s really going on, with Russia, the Commies here, the investigations. Thank you.
Where did you serve?
Korea. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 55.
And you’re how old...?
(proudly) Next month I’1l be twenty. She has no words, just looks at this boy, struck to her c

March, 1951. An Appaloosa horse stands against the mounta range, lazily dipping its head to chew grass, then raisin to scan the horizon. Nearby, Cleo focuses her camera on the majestic animal. S CLICKS off several shots. Chris is nearby, holding spare film canisters and lenses.
Mom.
Mm?

I've got a new one. She glances at Chris, who uses his hands to shove his che in toward each other -- then smiles, making his mouth kin a chubby vertical smile. Cleo chuckles and aims her camer at him.
Mom! She turns. Her daughter is at the back door of the main house.
You better come quick! INT. LAZY-T RANCH —- LIVING ROOM - DAY Chris and Cleo enter, Niki crouched in front of the enorm radio, dialing a clearer reception.
...ever been a member of the Communist Party? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 56.
I am not now nor have I ever been a member of that party, no... INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS

..-I have always been a liberal Democrat. Robinson is in the same seat Trumbo occupied. But no long a packed circus, it is now a rehearsed degradation ceremo Robinson speaks into radio microphones splayed before him he looks into the eyes of Investigator Robert Stripling.
But in your home, over the years, there have been political meetings. Attended by those we now know to be Communists.
Yes sir, yes, that has now been made clear to me... there were tremendous activities that went on in my house during the war...
A cinder-block Texas facility on a brown, scrubby flat.
..-but I did not know then their true affiliations... the work they were up to...
Arlen Hird lies in a bed among A DOZEN other infirm PRISONERS, hearing through an old oaken radio:
...the lies... Most of these prisoners could not care less -- but Hird i gravely riveted by Robinson’s testimony. EDWARD G. ROBINSON (ON RADIO) (CONT’D) ...the deception.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 57.

Most PRISONERS ignore the hearing CRACKLING on a small ra but a FEW, including Virgil Brooks and Trumbo, listen. Congressman Thomas, wiping down tables, is far away... bu listens intently, glancing occasionally at -- Trumbo, stony, a flicker of sadness in his eyes --
-- as Robinson’s eyes harden, a man determined --
I was duped and used. I was lied to.
-- Cleo’s eyes close. The kids are transfixed.
Who used you? INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS
Well, these... sinister forces who ran these... organizations in which I became a member, these.... uh, so- called Communist fronts.
Tell us the names of individuals.
Trumbo and Thomas, across the room from one another, both wait.
(after a beat) Mr. Robinson? INT. U.S. CAPITOL - CAUCUS ROOM —- CONTINUOUS
Well, you had Albert Maltz, uh, Ring Lardner, Jr., and that top fellow who they say is the, uh, commissar out there... (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 58.
Arlen Hird?
Yes...
Arlen Hird is unflinching as he hears --
.--Arlen Hird. Waldo Salt, Ian McLellan Hunter.
And Dalton... -- as is Trumbo --
...Trumbo. -- Robinson feels relief, hoping this is all now behind h
Brooks looks at the radio, disgusted, as we hear --
But at the time, it never entered my mind that any of these people were Communists...
(to Trumbo) That guy’s a friend of yours? (no response from Trumbo) Lucky he’s out there. And though he speaks to Trumbo, he speaks at Thomas:
Snitch like that in here, you’re fuckin’ dead. Trumbo leaves a terrified Thomas with a smiling Brooks.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 59.

BUSTLING. CROWDED. Edward G. Robinson is seated. Waiting. His eyes flick to a closed door. Stenciled on it: JOHN WAYNE, PRESIDENT. INT. MOTION PICTURE ALLIANCE - WAYNE’S OFFICE - CONTINUOU Wayne, Roy Brewer, Hedda and a FEW OTHERS meet.
Eddie oughta go back to work, he did what he had to.
He did what he was forced to.
Point is, he did it.

Brave men are fighting this battle, sacrificing in ways we can’t even imagine, and you talk about some asshole’s “career”? I’d see Eddie Robinson and everyone like him dead if it’d bring one boy back from Korea. One.
So what’re you saying? Guys like Eddie cooperate and get nothin’? (then) That isn’t right.
Careful, Duke.

Or what, Hedda? They stare at each other, neither moving or blinking. JOHN WAYNE (CONT’D) If I’m not careful. What? The room is frozen, cigarette smoke the only moving thing Then Hedda breaks the tension with a quick smile.
I had no idea you were such a softie. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 60.
Wayne studies her, then allows himself a grin.
That’s me. All cuddles.
Wayne walks Robinson out.
I’m proud of ya, Eddie.
(flat, far off) Thanks, Duke.
Wasn’t easy, I know, but ya did good. I’m gonna call the studios, the offers’1ll pour in. (off Robinson’s mute nod) Y’ okay?
Sure. Thanks. And tell Hedda... (beat) Give her my love, willya?
Not sure she'd know what to do with it. That is one hard broad.
Of the end of the ROSENBERG espionage trial. The Couple h been found guilty of selling atomic secrets to Russia and sentenced to death, then...
Of SENATOR JOSEPH McCARTHY’S rise as he purports to uncov Communists throughout the United States.

Spring, 1951. The same room where Trumbo was stripped nak and examined upon his entrance. Now he is back in his sui tie and overcoat. His wedding ring, lighter, cigarette ca and holder are returned by a GUARD.  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 61.
A taxi idles. Cleo waits. A SILHOUETTE approaches on the other side of the closed gate, which RUMBLES open, reveal Trumbo, now free. Cleo smiles, they move into one another last and kiss, then --
-- Trumbo drowns in the hugs of Chris, 10, and Mitzi, 6.
Giants! What have you huge, beautiful strangers done with my little ones? Niki appears in a dress. Tall. Almost 13. A young woman. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Good God. (as he moves to her) Lipstick?

(embarrassed) Da-aaad. He takes her hands and kisses her cheek. Then the five reunited Trumbos move into the house, REVEALING: A “FOR SALE” sign on a fence and tacked across it: “SOLD. INT. CHASEN’S - DAY CROWDED. Trumbo enters and sees Arlen Hird at the far end the bar, makes his way to him, as a KNOT OF BUSINESSMEN c his path. Trumbo bumps one.
Pardon me, I’m terribly -- It’s Buddy Ross. Trumbo is delighted. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Buddy. How are you? Buddy is highly aware of the men in his group, watching h
(to Trumbo, icy) I got nothin’ to say to you. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 62.
Buddy turns and strides off, followed by the men, all of WHISPER to each other. INT. CHASEN’S - AT THE BAR - LATER Trumbo and Hird sip their cocktails.
So. Jail’s given us the plague.
Buddy was always an asshole. He glances into the restaurant dining area, where he can Buddy animatedly making a pitch to that group of men.

And he’s in trouble. Three movies, three flops. (re: Buddy’s sweaty chatter) Look at him. Tryin’ to sell his soul but can’t find it. Just hope he stays afloat long enough to get the shit sued out of him.
By whom?
You, me, all of us, go on the offensive this time, sue the studios, all these guys, use their own capitalist system against them, in civil court -- make ‘em admit under oath --
-- No, no, no, Jesus, haven’t you spent enough time in court? I have.
What do you, got a better idea?
Do the one thing everyone says we can’t. Work.
Trumbo crosses a courtyard of slouching palms and tobacco colored bungalows, the offices of: KING BROTHERS PICTURES (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 63.
Look. You're a great writer...
Trumbo sits across from a beefy, harried, vaguely menacin man in his 40s named:
-..we make shit. I don’t see it.
Mr. King, I’m a screenwriter. If I couldn’t write shit, I’d starve. On the walls, lurid posters of King Brothers movies: star free gangster, horror, sci-fi and western quickies.
We can’t afford you.
How much did you pay for the script of... (points to western poster) ...that?
Twelve-hundred bucks.
I'll write you a movie for twelve hundred, then.
And you don’t want your name on it.
No, you don’t want my name on it.
You got that right... And in a corner WE REVEAL Frank’s younger brother, HYMIE, owlish and clenched with worry.
..-especially if you’re still... y'know... up to stuff. Are ya?
Perpetually. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 64.
Jesus.
Got any ideas?
Well, I just got out of prison, how about crime? The story of a gangster, his rise and fall?
I've seen that a few times.
Because it always makes money.
And when do I get the product?
(rising) Three days.
A hundred page script in three days? You tryin’ to fuck me? You fuck me and I will fuck you --
Mr. King, I’ve heard this speech. It was better in jail.
Trumbo writes, cigarette fuming like a factory chimney. T shelves are stripped, moving boxes piled everywhere. He arches, his back hurting so much he actually stops.
Trumbo is naked in the tub again. He adds scotch to his coffee and scribbles on typed scripts, pain-free.
Trumbo waits in the room’s only guest chair. A CURVACEOUS RECEPTIONIST hunts flies with a swatter. A door jerks open and a flushed Frank King stands hugely the doorway, holding a script. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 65.

Are you kiddin’ me with this? Trumbo looks up at him, alarmed. The Receptionist freezes mid-swat. Frank lunges at Trumbo, grabs his right hand, shakes it hard, then YELLS into another doorway: FRANK KING (CONT’D) Hymie! Get out here! Pay the man! Hymie emerges, pulls out a roll of cash, peels off fiftie FRANK KING (CONT’D) Now look, we got this one, killer in a swamp? Best character’s the swamp. Plus, women in prison, fighting in their underwear -- it’s perfect except it stinks. (to Hymie) What else?
Pirates. Can’t afford the ocean.
Fix ‘em all.

1952. A working-class section of Los Angeles. Small, neat houses; older cars. On this Sunday, MEN in sport shirts t to both, while WOMEN walk baby carriages or trim flowers KIDS play. A moving truck RUMBLES past, followed by --

INT. /EXT. TRUMBO’S CAR - DRIVING/HIGHLAND PARK - CONTINU Trumbo at the wheel, Cleo beside him, the three kids in b all taking in this new block. Trumbo’s gaze settles on a presidential election lawn sig EISENHOWER/NIXON, featuring photos of the two candidates. Trumbo focuses on Nixon’s wide grin.
Lovely, compact. MOVERS unload furniture from their truck Niki pours lemonade for some who take a break.
Hard work, you holding up okay?  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 66.
Beside a shimmering pool, Trumbo and Mitzi tend to a tiny injured bird. She is upset, Trumbo warmly calm.
It’s a broken wing but he’s going to be just fine, sweetie.
He’s scared.
We'll get him some water, some nice, yummy worms, go inside, ask mom for a shoebox. She runs into the house. Trumbo cups the bird.
The house has been completely moved into. Cleo comes down the stairs in a bathing suit.
C'mon, Mitzi! Mitzi races down the stairs, also in a bathing suit. Moth and daughter cross through the house, excited. They pass YAWNING Trumbo still in his robe. He opens the front door
-- to get the paper and lying next to it, sees a plain envelope. Trumbo picks it up and opens it. It reads in block letter

head_text.subj: WELCOME TRAITOR. WE DID THE POOL.

text: Alarmed, Trumbo hurries out to --
-- where Cleo comforts Mitzi, upset as Trumbo exits the h to see -- -- their pool fouled with garbage, dirt, floating dead ra Trumbo immediately moves to his wife and child.
All right. Inside. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 67.
He glances across his fence and sees his NEXT-DOOR NEIGHB 30s, tight white t-shirt, watering his lawn. And an unmistakably big, shit-eating grin on his face.
Trumbo presides over the family dinner.
There are many ignorant, angry people in the world. And they appear to be breeding in record numbers. All we can do is stay together and remain vigilant.

Fall, 1953, as WE FIND the bright marquee, announcing: Roman Holiday. Starring Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn. Below that, a lit poster for the breezy romantic comedy. TIGHT on the movie’s credits and ISOLATE: Original Story by Ian McLellan Hunter.
Among the ROWS of MOVIE FANS, Dalton and Cleo Trumbo enjo lovely, funny scene, LAUGHING with the rest of the audien though perhaps with a bit more restraint.
Big hit, great reviews -- INT. DINER —- DOWNTOWN L.A. - DAY
-- haven’t worked in nine months. Trumbo sips coffee. Hunter reaches for the cream.
You?
There aren’t quite enough zeroes in a King Brothers salary to survive --
Trumbo at the typewriter, surrounded by empty shelves. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 68.
-- but they need scripts like an army needs food. Quality, minimal; quantity, maximal.

head_text.subj: THIS OFFICE MORPHS OVER THE YEAR

text: As Trumbo writes, never leaving the desk, as if chained. WITHOUT A SINGLE CUT, all around him, the shelves fill wi scripts, the office growing more and more cluttered.
Every work week is seven days, every day is fourteen hours, every minute I’m behind. And I’m becoming a stranger in my own home.
INT. DINER —- DOWNTOWN L.A. - DAY
They need five of you. Trumbo smiles slyly.

Of FIVE MEN, including Ian McLellan Hunter and Arlen Hird Though they’re sipping cocktails and coffee, they have th clenched look of people in the middle of a job interview. Which is not far from the truth because --
The only question is, can these pinkos write?
Sit, the Kings looking over the table of writers like use goods at a garage sale:
(points) That’s Ian McLellan Hunter.
(impressed) Guy wrote Roman Holiday.
Guy just got subpoenaed. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 69.
Guy just got nominated.

Everyone at that table’s been nominated. Frank nods. A waiter delivers drinks as a BUXOM STARLET bends to whisper to Frank, who nods, kisses her hand, sen her along. Hymie looks faintly ill with dread. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) It'd be like this... I find the writer and work with him. He delivers the script to me. If it’s good, I'll give it to you, if it’s bad, I'll fix it. Nobody gets paid till you're happy.
(scared, whispers) And these writers are... all... all, uh...
Blacklisted, Jesus, you’re such a chickenshit.
Y'know, we’re at war with the Communists.
No, we’re not.
It’s a new kind of war.
Yeah, doesn’t exist, very new.
What about the Rosenbergs?
What about ‘em?
They stole the atom bomb.
They didn’t steal it off a fuckin’ camera truck. (CONTINUED)

Four of the five writers try to appear blandly appealing. Only Arlen waves, coquettish. Hunter throws him a glare. FRANK KING (CONT’D) (to Trumbo, earnestly) Look. We bought a gorilla suit. And we gotta use it.
Hird, Hunter and the other blacklistees confer with Trumb
So you had five jobs, now we got ‘em all and you got none?
I’m now free to go get five more jobs and five more writers. Then you each get five more jobs, five more writers --
To keep that going, we’d need to write every script in the business.
(faux innocence) What a thought, Arlen. Lord, you're a devious lad. (then) So who wants to write a gorilla movie?
Who doesn’t?
Trumbo stands. His wife and three children sit.
We now work at midnight, in thick fog, among strangers. The four Trumbos stare at him, all confused. DALTON TRUMBO (CONT’D) Not... literally. (then) We’re running a family business.
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 71.
We’ll be adding new phone lines. A phone on a table. Then ANOTHER DISSOLVES IN alongside i Then ANOTHER. One RINGS.
When you answer, never say “Trumbo residence,” just -- Chris, 12, picks up the phone.
Hello. A MAN’S VOICE (ON PHONE) Is John Abbott there?
Whoever they ask for, find me or --
No, sir, may I take a message? He listens as he writes a message for “John Abbott.”
The door must be answered at all hours.
A DOORBELL CHIMES. Mitzi, 8, opens it. A UNIFORMED MESSENGER stands, checking a clipboard.

Got a pickup from... Sally Stubblefield? Mitzi checks a side table stacked with large envelopes, f the one marked “Sally Stubblefield” and hands it to the Messenger. MESSENGER (CONT’D) Can I get your dad to sign? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 72.
She scribbles on the clipboard like a pro and shuts the d
Dictation, short hand and typing will be learned. Those of legal age will have one of the most important jobs imaginable.
A scruffy little independent company.

Courier. Cleo’s car pulls up, she exits, moves to a delivery entra The door opens. A WOMAN’S HAND holds out an envelope. INT. TRUMBO’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Cleo checks the envelope, fat with twenty-dollar bills.
(to his family) Questions? Comments? Niki raises her hand.
Is there a schedule?
A what.
I need to know when I can do homework. And I’m on a fundraising committee for Negro Voting Rights, plus --
All right, honey, we'll work it out. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 73.
(as Trumbo begins to object, she throws him a look) Won't we. He doesn’t answer. Trumbo and Niki lock eyes in uneasy silence.
Niki watches a bulky new television set, the picture jitt ON TV —- AFRICAN-AMERICAN PROTESTERS In actual black & white news footage MARCH outside school
.--and protests continued as the Supreme Court takes up the issue of racial segregation...
Then pulls rough copy from his carriage and holds it out Niki, but she is riveted by --

.--while throughout the nation, heated debate over integration... -- until she sees the page he proffers, SIGHS, takes it, moves to a second typewriter and begins HAMMERING out the final carbon, her eyes straying to the TV images of PROTE

Trumbo is alone, the TV is off. Trumbo opens a drawer, ta out a pill bottle, shakes out one tablet, then decides tw would be better. As he pops them in his mouth, Cleo appears in the doorway question on her lips. She sees her husband down the pills with a shot of scotch. She quickly decides the question c wait and retreats.
Hunter, Hird and Trumbo sit as Frank King gives “notes.”
(picks up a script) Which one’s “Graham Topper”? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 74.

The three writers look at one another, unsure. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Nympho nun. Ah. Hunter raises his hand. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Great job. He hands Hunter his script back. FRANK KING (CONT’D) “Elwood Carr”? Murder at the circus? Trumbo nods, King slides him the script. FRANK KING (CONT’D) Needs work. I knew it was the clown.
(consoling Trumbo) It’s always the clown. Now King levels a malevolent gaze at Hird.
So. You’re the alien and the farm girl.
Yeah.

You wrote... He opens the script to the middle, showing pages and page and pages of single-spaced, typewritten speeches. FRANK KING (CONT’D) ...the alien talking about “the rights of workers,” the “pathology of capitalism”? (enraged) The “dialectic”? I don’t even know what that IS and I fucking hate it.
All right, so it’s a little dense -- (CONTINUED)

I pay for a script about a guy with a giant bug head balling a girl in a haystack, you give me shit that’1ll get me subpoenaed. And also? Stinks! (then) Never. Again. Fix it. But that last was not to Hird, it was to Trumbo. As King shoots the script across the table at him.
Hird and Trumbo go over Hird’s screenplay.
Oh, fuck Frank King.
(scribbling in the script margins) I said, until he’s happy, I rewrite.
So you’re gonna stay up all night with this crap, to what, get it to his high literary, political standards?
It shouldn’t be to anyone’s political standards. What the hell were you thinking...? Hird snatches Trumbo’s pen. Trumbo glares at him.

I was thinking. It’s why I'ma writer. To say things that matter. Jesus Christ, look at us. (then) I was a reporter, I got nominated for a Pulitzer, I fought in Spain! I know Ernest Hemingway! I actually, I know him! And he knows me! I walk into a bar in Paris, he’d -- maybe he doesn’t know my name but... (then) You won the National fucking Book Award. What're we doing?
(CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 76.
Trumbo stands and moves to the bar. He takes two glasses.
The two men, several drinks in, fairly hammered, trying t work.
So the alien... the alien... why does he... want to impregnate the farm girl? To start a race... propagate, so they can all take over...
(shakes head) She's cute. Hird considers this solemnly. Then --
Uh. Fine. (a defeated pause) I mean, don’t you ever miss writing something, forget great, just good? You gotta have actual ideas... still... don’t you? Trumbo smokes. Then:

A few. One keeps buzzing around up there... won’t go away. Cleo and I were in Mexico at a bullfight, years ago. Bull died and... a thousand people cheered. Three didn’t. Cleo, me... and a little boy down front. Crying. I always wondered why.
You write it, you'll know. Just, promise me, not for Frank King.
The day I don’t have to and just want to.
Spring, 1954, Oscar Night, the Trumbos, minus Niki, eat snacks and chat. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 77.
Niki! Hurry! The sound of a toilet FLUSHING, then feet running.
(racing in) Who's doing it?
Kirk Douglas! As they all settle and watch their black & white TV --
38 years old, chiseled and dashing in white tie and tails

...the envelope? And the Oscar goes to... (pulls out the card) .--Roman Holiday! By Ian McLellan Hunter! The THEME from Roman Holiday and APPLAUSE, while Douglas scans for the writer who will never appear.
Sit for a moment, not sure how to react to this, until --
So, do we get to be happy now?
Trumbo, Hunter and between them: that gold Oscar statuett
I don’t want it.
Well, I don’t want it.
Your name’s on it.
You wrote it.
They gave it to you. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 78.
And it’s done me wonders. (hands Trumbo a script) Here’s the gorilla movie. Chris enters.
Phone for you, Dad.
Which name?
No. You. Some guy named Buddy Ross. Trumbo is surprised as he picks up the extension.
(teasing, into phone) Buddy who...? INT. ROSS INTERNATIONAL - BUDDY’S OFFICE - NIGHT This is not the Buddy Ross we've known. He vibrates with exhausted panic as he takes a seat near Trumbo.
So’s it true, the rumor? You wrote Roman Holiday? Trumbo just looks at him, then --
What can I do for you, Buddy? Buddy hesitates, barely knowing where to begin.

My movies’ve all bombed, dug me into a hole. I finally got something going. Classy. Three big stars. The script... (he can’t finish) What script, there’s no script, I got eleven writers who fucked me, now the actors’re gonna pull out ‘n’ if they do, I lose everything.
When do you shoot? (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 79.
Ten days.
Is there anything? He hands Trumbo three typed pages. Trumbo studies them.
There'd be no credit, obviously, I can’t pay you till we start shooting, and I wouldn’t blame you if you spit in my face. But we did good stuff, back then, we really did. Please?
Trumbo and Hird.
I owe the Kings a rewrite, I can’t do both, I need you to take over.
So you can help out that great guy, Buddy Ross.
So we can keep tearing down the blacklist.
Oh, Jesus, here we go...
This is a huge movie, if Buddy gets a good script --
-- which you’re gonna give him --
-- which I’m going to sell him.
Yep. Money. Always money. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 80.
Why do you not see this? We get one big movie, we could get all the big movies and the whole rotten thing’1l collapse from the sheer irony that every unemployable writer is employed.
Jesus, do you ever say anything that isn’t gonna get chiselled on a rock?

Near an open window overlooking the back patio, Cleo drie some dishes at the sink. Trumbo and Hird’s ARGUMENT can b heard but is muffled by doors and walls. Cleo HUMS to herself, as nearby -- Chris cleans his trumpet, while Mitzi tends to another wounded bird. Mitzi catches Cleo’s eye and -- Cleo smiles and TOSSES a water glass into the air, then a second, then a third, JUGGLING them. Mitzi LAUGHS with delight, Chris smiles then --
(suddenly loud) .-.-I am not gonna help you help Buddy Ross! The kids are startled --
We should be suing that cockroach into the ground, along with every studio, congressman, producer --
-- as is Cleo, who manages to keep the glasses aloft --
(exploding) Brilliant -- !  TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 81.
-- keep losing, give all your money to lawyers --
I'd rather lose for the right reason than --
(roaring)
Cleo’s deft hands flutter, a glass FUMBLES off her finger and HITS the floor in an EXPLOSION of shards -- INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS
It’s LOSING!
Cleo sweeps her children out.
C'mon, kids, we're going to the store.
(to Cleo) But --
I lose -- !
(to her kids) Now.
-- you lose -- !
Which store?
-- we ALL lose -- ! (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 82.
Any store. Cleo’s calm but sharp demeanor is not to be ignored. The kids follow her out. INT. TRUMBO HIGHLAND PARK HOUSE —- STUDY - CONTINUOUS
-- and the whole goddamn country stays scared and dead! You want to live like this forever? Or do something? We can beat them, we can win!
I don’t care if I win --
-- Oh, bullshit, everyone wants to win --
No, you wanna win, I wanna change things.
I want to win so I can change things --
No, you want the Oscar you can’t have and the money you burn through writing shit for idiots.
Why do I have to explain everything like you’re a fucking child? A beat, as Hird retreats quietly...
You don’t. Okay? You don’t. (heads for exit) Do what you do. It’s fine. For you. Trumbo, sensing he’s perhaps gone too far --
(calming) Arlen... (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 83.
I know what I’m fighting for. You want another lake. And you know what? You’re gonna get it. Hird is gone. Trumbo is alone in the sudden quiet.
Trumbo sits, still and silent, smoke curling off the cigarette in his fingers, staring at a blank typewriter p
The tub is full of hot water, Trumbo is in there, writing about half-speed, pausing every few words to smoke and ru his head.
Cleo drops off a script to the Secretary, gets the cash envelope.

Trumbo in the tub again, writing at top speed as WE RACK FOCUS TO that pill bottle we saw in his office. And REVEA here it’s Benzedrine. From downstairs, he can just barely hear CHEERFUL FAMILY VOICES --
Niki, just turning 16 now, blows out the candles on her birthday cake. APPLAUSE from Cleo, Chris and Mitzi, all hugging her.
You sure we shouldn’t go knock?
I’m sure. Niki stares at her smoking candles, angry.
He can’t take five minutes -- ?
No.
(testing) Two minutes. One minute. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 84.
Chris. Get the good plates.
I’ll do it. She exits and --
-- parks herself outside the closed bathroom door. She hesitates, then KNOCKS. The typing STOPS.
Dad? We’re having birthday cake. The door flies open and there’s Trumbo, soaked, half-in h robe, enraged.
When I’m working, you don’t knock!
But it’s my --
You don’t knock! Ever!
So the house is on fire, you don’t want to know?
I work in a BATHTUB! Surrounded by WATER! So even if the whole WORLD catches fire --

(raging at Niki) -- I can still be this family’s personal goddamn SLAVE and all I ask is not to be interrupted for every fucking slice of FUCKING CAKE you see fit to -- ! Cleo appears, slicing a look into Trumbo that shames him silence. He takes a breath, all is still, then he SLAMS t door and is gone. Niki, terrified and humiliated, runs do the hall, crying. (CONTINUED)
TRUMBO —- JOHN MCNAMARA 85.
Cleo stands, unsure what to do. She lifts her hand to kno on the bathroom door, again hears TYPING and thinks bette it. She then follows the sound of her daughter’s SOBS.
A bone-tired Trumbo heads for the master bedroom. Through the open door, he sees the bluish flicker of a black & wh TV and some familiar words from long ago... EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (V.O.,
What do you want? What we all want.
Trumbo enters, sees Cleo watching an old movie on TV. It’ the one from MGM, 1947. Trumbo is transfixed.

Smoothly acted, shot and cut together under lush MUSIC: EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) To not die young, poor or alone. “ROCCO” (ON TV) Manny, these guys... I don’t give ‘em what they’re after, they’ll kill me. “Rocco” starts to go. EDWARD G. ROBINSON/”MANNY” (ON TV) Hold it, Rocco. “Manny” takes out his revolver -- and aims it at “Rocco,” freezes. EDWARD G.
